This doesn't exactly answer your question, but
we use EMMA on the projects =
I work on.  It's not
integrated with Eclipse, but it works well and
is free=
.  I haven't really found great need to
integrate my coverage tool with my =
IDE, because
of the way I use it.  I'm usually interested in
running a whol=
e bunch of tests and then seeing
how my coverage looks for the whole suite.=
  Then,
I drill down, notice I missed some methods or
classes or whatever, =
and then go write tests for
those.  Maybe I'm not using coverage analysis t=
o
its full benefit, but I don't really do coverage
in small iterations (unl=
ike TDD with JUnit).


Todd.

 Subject: [junit] [OT] coverage plugins for eclipse?

> Apologies if this=
 is OT, but IMHO coverage measurement (for 
> guiding one's test writing) a=
nd IDEs (for writing and running 
> one's tests) are both at least tangenti=
ally related to JUnit 
> ... and I don't know of a good list for coverage m=
easurement :-(
> 
> I'm wondering, what are folks who use Eclipse (or Eclip=
se-based
> products) using to do coverage measurement and reporting? One 
>=
 option is to just run the coverage tool from the command line 
> or ant, b=
ut I'd really like something more integrated, e.g.
> 
> 0 a run config that=
 would Run>{JUnit, JUnit Plug-in Test} under the
>   coverage tool and disp=
lay results in a view
> 
> 1 mark un/covered sources in Outline view or edi=
tors
> 
> The coverage plugins of which I'm aware are
> 
> * Clover
> 
> * =
jcoverage
> 
> * Rational Developer (Unfortunately its coverage tools are p=
art of its
>   performance-testing tools, which complicates installation an=
d use
>   for "normal" testing.)
> 
> Are there others?
